sec.title: Abstract
sec.p:
The genus
Galapa Huber, 2000
includes tiny spiders (body length < 1.5 mm ) restricted to semi-arid habitats. It has long been thought to be endemic to the Galapagos Islands until
G. spiniphila Huber, 2020
was described from the Venezuelan Paraguaná Peninsula. Here, we support this generic assignment with molecular (CO1) data and describe two new species from Colombia (
G. gabito Huber
sp. n. ) and Costa Rica (
G. murphyi Huber
sp. n. ), showing that the genus is actually widely distributed. Distribution modelling identifies several high suitability areas for
Galapa
, all of which are poorly sampled with respect to Pholcidae (ranging from Nicaragua to northern Peru and Guiana ). Our results suggest a strong sampling bias against spiders restricted to dry tropical regions and habitats.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Recent focused collecting in dry regions suggests that we have a biased view regarding Ninetinae species diversity. For example, a recent campaign in semi-arid Brazilian biomes has resulted in over 1500 adult specimens representing approximately 30 species of Ninetinae , most of them new to science (B.A. Huber & L.S. Carvalho, unpubl. data). Recent and ongoing revisions resulted and will result in substantial increases in the numbers of known species. For example, a recent revision of the southern South American genus
Nerudia Huber, 2000
increased the species number from one to ten (
); an ongoing revision of the South American genus
Ibotyporanga Mello-Leitão, 1944
will increase the species number from five to 24 (B.A. Huber et al. , unpubl. data).

sec.title: Material and methods
sec.p: Material examined

This study is based on the examination of more than 200 adult specimens of
Galapa
deposited in the following institutions: Invertebrates Collection of the Charles Darwin Research Station, Galápagos , Ecuador (ICCDRS); Muséum d'Histoire Naturelle, Genève , Switzerland ( MHNG ); Manchester Museum, University of Manchester , Great Britain ( MMUE ); Museo de Entomología de la Universidad del Valle, Cali, Colombia (MUSENUV); and Zoologisches Forschungsmuseum Alexander Koenig, Bonn, Germany ( ZFMK ). Further material deposited in Institut Royal des Sciences Naturelles de Belgique , Brussels (IRSNB) and California Academy of Sciences, San Francisco (CAS) was examined by the first author in 1999 but not re-examined for the present study. ZFMK material with Ar codes is kept in 80% ethanol at room temperature; material with other codes is in pure ethanol at -18°C.

sec.title: Taxonomy and Morphology
Molecular analysis
sec.p:
Taxonomic sampling. We newly generated CO1 barcodes of 13 specimens of representatives of
Galapa
( Table 1 ). To this we added CO1 barcodes of five outgroup species belonging to closely related genera (according to upcoming analyses of UCE data; G. Meng, L Podsiadlowski, B.A Huber, unpubl. data): four from
: S347
Guaranita yaculica Huber
; JA83
Pemona sapo Huber
; S328
Kambiwa neotropica (Kraus)
; S358
Kambiwa sp.
“MACN273”; and one from
: N037
Guaranita goloboffi Huber. For
rooting the tree, we used two more distantly related Ninetinae taken from
: JA123
Ibotyporanga naideae Mello-Leitão
and S443
Ibotyporanga sp.
“Br16-149”. The complete set of analyzed taxa is listed in Supplementary File, Table S1 .

DNA extraction, amplification, and sequencing. Two to four legs of specimens stored in non-denatured pure ethanol (~99%) at -20° C were used for DNA extraction. Extracted genomic DNA is deposited at and available from the LIB Biobank, Museum Koenig, Bonn. DNA was extracted using the BioSprint® 96 DNA Blood Kit (Qiagen). The CO1 primers used were LCO1490-JJ and HCO2198-JJ (
; primer versions JJ2 served as backup). The 20 µl reaction volume consisted of 4.4 µl H 2 O, 2 µl DNA template, 2 µl Q-Solution, 10 µl Qiagen Multiplex-Mix, 0.8 µl forward primer and 0.8 µl reverse primer. The PCR program ran two cycle sets, as a combination of a ‘touchdown’ and a ‘step-up’ routine: (1) 15 min hot start Taq activation at 95°C; (2) first cycle set (15 repeats): 35 s denaturation at 94°C, 90 s annealing at 55°C (−1°C per cycle) and 90 s extension at 72°C; (3) second cycle set (25 repeats): 35 s denaturation at 94°C, 90 s annealing at 40°C, and 90 s extension at 72°C; (4) final elongation 10 min at 72°C. PCR products were sent for bidirectional Sanger sequencing to BGI ( Hong Kong , China ).

sec.title: Sampling bias and biogeographic analyses
sec.p:
We hypothesized that the apparently disjunct distribution of the genus
Galapa
is explained by sampling bias. We further expected that representatives of
Galapa
occur at similar environmental conditions throughout the range of the genus. We tested these hypotheses using two approaches. First, we did a distribution modelling for the genus and compared areas with high suitability with known records of pholcids in general. Second, we compared altitude and aridity among
Galapa
populations and other pholcids from the same regions.

The altitudes and the aridity indices of localities where
Galapa
representatives have been recorded were compared using generalized linear models. Due to overdispersion issues, we used a quasipoisson distribution of errors. Post hoc contrast analyses were performed using the ‘coms’ function in the R package ‘RT4Bio’ (
). Altitude was chosen due to the results of the distribution modelling, suggesting that
Galapa
representatives occupy low altitude areas. For this analysis, we used the raw altitude data gathered upon collecting each specimen (most records). Alternatively, for ca. 2% of the records, we extracted altitude data based on the geographic coordinates using the altitude raster from WorldClim 2.1 (
). The aridity index was chosen as it was the most important variable for the first axis of a PCA using Pholcidae occurrences based on records from the study area.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Molecular analysis

Figure 1 shows a neighbor-joining tree of all available CO1 sequences of
Galapa
. For the complete tree, including outgroups, see Supplementary File, Fig. S1 . Genetic distances among the sequenced specimens of
Galapa
are shown in Table 2 . For the complete table showing all distances among all specimens analyzed in this study, see Supplementary File, Table S2 . The average genetic (K2P) distance between
Galapa
specimens and Ninetinae outgroups was 21.7% (18.3–24.7%, N=91). Among species of
Galapa
, the average distance was slightly lower, at 17.9% (13.5–23.4%; N=63). Within the species of
Galapa
, the average distance was 6.2% (0.5–10.1%; N=15). This wide range is due to the fact that several specimens that show slight morphological variation are included and assigned tentatively to one of the nominal species. The average distance between these problematic specimens and nominal conspecifics to which they were assigned was 9.2% (8.2–10.2%; N=8). Excluding these problematic specimens and counting only unproblematic conspecifics, the average distance was 2.7% (0.5–4.8%; N=7).

,

(in terms of body size, body shape, coloration, leg length, and simple epigynal plate); distinguished from these by internal genitalia: large membranous structure (

In general, similar to males but sternum without pair of anterior humps, chelicerae without stridulatory files (
,

,

,

,
,
,
) very simple, apparently without pore plates; with large membranous structure (with or without median membranous process), either directed towards posterior and covered by posterior epigynal plate or directed towards anterior and covered by anterior epigynal plate.

Relationships . Molecular (UCE) data (G. Meng, L. Podsiadlowski, B.A. Huber, unpubl. data) suggest that the closest known relative of
Galapa
is an undescribed species from Brazil , Piauí , Parque Nacional da Serra da Capivara. That species is known from a single male specimen that does not share any of the diagnostic genital characters of
Galapa
listed above. Together, these two clades are sister to
Kambiwa
+
Pemona
, two further South American genera. All of these together are sister of the southern South American genus
Guaranita
. Thus,
Galapa
is deeply nested within South American Ninetinae .

Even though a NJ tree (
) is not supposed to reliably reflect phylogeny, it shows two splits worth mentioning. First, within
Galapa
,
G. bella
( Galapagos ) is sister to the mainland species. Several morphological characters support this split: (1) Mainland species share a proximal ridge on the basis of the leg trichobothria; in
G. bella
, these bases are round, which is likely the plesiomorphic condition; (2) in mainland species, the male palpal tarsal organ has moved to the procursus, while in
G. bella
it has the plesiomorphic position on the tarsus; (3) in mainland species, the female internal genitalia are directed towards posterior, while in
G. bella
they are directed towards anterior, which is probably the plesiomorphic condition; (4) finally, body size and leg length are smaller in mainland species than in species from Galapagos (carapace width: ~0.4 vs. ~0.5; tibia 1 length:>0.60 versus <0.55); the plesiomorphic condition is unknown.

Second, the Central American (Costa Rican)
G. murphyi
is nested within a group of mainland South American species. This position is supported by the loss of epiandrous spigots in
G. murphyi
and
G. spiniphila
, while
G. bella
and
G. gabito
share the plesiomorphic presence of four epiandrous spigots.

Distribution . The genus is known from Galápagos, northern Colombia , northeastern Venezuela , and Costa Rica (
). The distribution map of these tiny and poorly collected spiders suggests a wide range, but the ecological conditions (semi-arid, exposed habitats; see below) are not common in this region, so the suitable habitats may actually be quite limited. This is supported by our biogeographic analysis (see below).
Composition . The genus now includes six nominal species: three on the Galápagos, one in Costa Rica (with a dubious record in Colombia ), and two in northern South America.

Distribution . Known from several localities on Santa Cruz Island, Galápagos . The single female reported from Santa Cruz, Islote Venecia (~ 0.5178°S , 90.4760°W ), by Gertsch & Peck (1992) , may also represent this species rather than
G. baerti
. The species has been claimed to be present on Genovesa and Pinta Islands (
Baert et al. 2008
; Baert 2013 , 2014 ) but without specimen and collection data, so these records are here considered dubious.

Natural history . At the type locality (Charles Darwin Research Station), the species seems to have been replaced by the introduced
Modisimus culicinus (Simon, 1893) ( Huber & Acurio 2022 )
. The specimens newly collected in 2019 (listed in Huber & Acurio 2022 ) were found in very dry and exposed habitats near the sea, under rocks and small stones and pebbles (
). At both localities (near Garrapatero beach and near Canal de Itabaca), the spiders occupied the drier upper layer of stones, while
Anopsicus banksi (Gertsch, 1939)
was found in the deeper, slightly more humid layers. The spiders ran very quickly when disturbed.

tp:treatment-sec.p:
Galapa spiniphila Huber
in Huber & Villarreal 2020: 58 , figs 174–175, 178–188 ( ♂ ♀ ). Diagnosis (amended; see Huber & Villarreal 2020 ). Males are distinguished from known congeners by presence of four distal apophyses on genital bulb (
,
; pair of ventral apophyses, distal apophysis, and retrolateral-dorsal apophysis) and by simple (not bifid) retrolateral process on procursus directed towards retrolateral (rather than towards dorsal). Females without sclerite in ventral wall of uterus externus (as opposed to
G. gabito
) but externally possibly indistinguishable from
G. murphyi
; large membranous structure in internal genitalia not bilobed as in
G. gabito
and
G. murphyi
, with distinctive median membranous process (arrows in
).

Remarks . The Colombian specimens below are assigned tentatively to this species because there are some minor but apparently consistent morphological differences among them and between Colombian and Venezuelan specimens (see Variation below and
). They are not described as separate species mainly because of the low CO1 distances among the sequenced Colombian specimens (3.3–4.8%). The distances between the Colombian specimens on one side and the topotypical Venezuelan
G. spiniphila
specimen on the other side are higher (9.4–10.1%), but the morphological differences between them are of the same degree as those among Colombian specimens. We thus describe the new Colombian specimens as morphs within
G. spiniphila
, pending further analysis. The topotypical morph is here named ‘Paraguaná morph’.
The specimens from Magdalena are extremely bleached and difficult to study.They seem to share the morphology of the Pueblo Bello morph.

Natural history . At Riohacha, all specimens were beaten out of dead cactus branches lying on the ground in a degraded roadside environment with bushes and a few small trees. At Papayal, most specimens were also beaten out of dead cacti lying on the ground in a similar roadside environment (
). At Pueblo Bello, the spiders were found in a low, dry forest on a roadside hill. They were beaten from old dry branches lying on the ground and hollowed by termites. At all three localities, they shared the used microhabitats with another species of Ninetinae , an undescribed representative of
Ibotyporanga
; at Riohacha, also with
Modisimus culicinus (Simon, 1893)
. Two egg-sacs contained six eggs each, with an egg diameter of 0.38–0.40.

Distribution . This species seems to be widespread in north-western Venezuela and northern Colombia (
).

published on goblin spiders collected by J. Murphy on the same day, and with the same ecological (“forest leaf litter”) and altitude data ( 90 m ), giving Cañas as locality. We thus assume that the specimens were collected in or near Cañas.
Description .

MEASUREMENTS.Total body length 1.12, carapace width 0.42. Distance PME-PME 40 µm; diameter PME 40 µm; distance PME-ALE 20 µm; distance AME-AME 10 µm; diameter AME 25 µm. Leg 1: 1.94 (0.52 + 0.14 + 0.50 + 0.46+ 0.32), tibia 2: 0.40, tibia 3: 0.34, tibia 4: 0.56; tibia 1 L/d: 9; diameters of leg femora 0.090, of leg tibiae: 0.055.
COLOUR (in ethanol). Prosoma and legs ochre-yellow, carapace without pattern, legs without darker rings; abdomen ochre-grey with indistinct internal marks.
Variation (male)

Tibia 1 in 20 other males from Guanacaste (except northern Guanacaste): 0.45–0.54 (mean 0.49). The male from northern Guanacaste ( 6 km S of La Cruz) differs slightly in the position and shape of the bifid retrolateral-distal process on the procursus (
—more proximal position on procursus; directed more towards lateral than towards proximal). In addition, the distal bulbal apophysis is slightly thinner, and the CO1 distances between a specimen from this locality and three other sequenced specimens were relatively high, at 9.4–10.1%. This male (and the accompanying specimens from this locality) are thus assigned tentatively to this species; tibia 1: 0.54. The three males from Colombia are in very bad condition (bleached) and thus difficult to compare; their palps are slightly smaller, but the bifid retrolateral-distal process on the procursus seems to be as in the holotype ; tibia 1: 0.48, 0.48, 0.54.
Female

Distribution . Known from several localities in Guanacaste , Costa Rica (
). Specimens from northern Guanacaste are assigned tentatively, either because the only available male differs slightly (see Variation above) and CO1 distances to other sequenced specimens are relatively high (9.4–10.1%), or because no adult specimens are available. sec.title: Sampling bias and biogeographic analyses
sec.p:
The principal component analysis (PCA) of the predictor layers used in the distribution modeling showed that only five axes explained more of the variance than expected by chance, i.e., more than 4.54% of the proportion of variance (Supplementary File, Table S3). These five axes explained 87.9% of the variance.The distribution modelling analysis attributed a higher importance to the second PC axis, which represented 72.6% of the contribution (Supplementary File, Table S4). This axis was most positively correlated with the precipitation of the wettest month and the mean temperature of the driest quarter, but negatively correlated with the mean diurnal range and precipitation seasonality (Supplementary File, Table S5). Areas with high relative occurrence rate (ROR) for
Galapa
were observed in several countries, showing a discontinuous pattern. Some of these areas (numbers 1–6 in Fig. 34A ) have no record of
Galapa
representatives. Other pholcids shared this sampling bias (see Discussion).

The altitude (d.f. = 7, resid. dev. = 968692, p = 0.000) and the aridity index (d.f. = 7, resid. dev. = 6623908, p = 0.000) were significantly different among the points of occurrences of Pholcidae taxa. Ninetines (including
Galapa
) and artemines (i.e., the Venezuelan
Chisosa caquetio Huber, 2019
) are known from significantly lower sites than those recorded for Pholcinae (mainly
Metagonia Simon, 1893
; Fig. 36A ). All these taxa together occur on average at significantly lower sites than representatives of Modisiminae ( Fig. 36A ). The aridity index, used herein as a surrogate for environmental conditions, was significantly lower for
Galapa
populations from Galapagos, Venezuela , Colombia , other Ninetinae , and Arteminae, than for other pholcids ( Fig. 36B ). The
Galapa
populations from Costa Rica , however, occur in regions with a similar aridity index as for Modisiminae and Pholcinae, i.e., in relatively more humid conditions ( Fig. 36B ).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p:
The disjunct distribution of
Galapa
is uncommon among Neotropical pholcids. Disregarding artifacts of wrong generic assignments (e.g., in
Coryssocnemis Simon, 1893
; probably also in
Psilochorus Simon, 1893
; cf.
: Appendix 3), only
Ibotyporanga Mello-Leitão, 1944
( Ninetinae ) and
Micropholcus Deeleman-Reinhold & Prinsen, 1987
(Pholcinae) have wide and disjunct distributions in the Neotropical region (
;
;
). Whether such distribution patterns are real or an artificial consequence of sampling bias remains to be established and will require focused sampling. In the present study, the distribution modelling suggested six geographic regions with high environmental suitability for representatives of
Galapa
( Figs 34 , 35 ) that should be prioritized for further sampling. These areas are situated in the coastal regions of Central America and in coastal and continental areas in northern South America ( Fig. 34A ).Additionally, it will be important for future campaigns to include Ninetinae as a priority-target. Previous studies have shown that the probability of collecting these spiders as a byproduct of general sampling tends to be low (
).

In the Galapagos archipelago, most lowland areas had a high relative occurrence rate (ROR; i.e., high environmental suitability for
Galapa
), while higher elevation areas presented a low ROR ( Fig. 34B ). In line with this result, extensive sampling of high altitude areas has not revealed any representative of
Galapa
(
,
;
). This is also consistent with our comparative analysis showing that representatives of
Galapa
live in low altitudinal regions ( Fig. 36A ). In this respect,
Galapa
is similar to other ninetines from Central America and northern South America, while some southern South American and North American ninetines occur at much higher altitudes (
, 2023b).

In the Caribbean Sea, several islands had a high ROR (e.g., Netherlands Antilles , Isla de Tortuga , and Isla de Margarita), while the eastern islands in the Lesser Antilles (i.e., Trinidad & Tobago , Grenada , etc.) had a low suitability ( Figs 34A , 35B ; see also Supplementary File, Fig. S7 ). Among the high ROR islands, Curaçao is of particular interest. It has been sampled intensively with a focus on Ninetinae (by BAH), which resulted in a high number of records and specimens of the Ninetinae genus
Papiamenta Huber, 2000
, while no representatives of
Galapa
were found ( Fig. 35B ). Therefore, the absence of
Galapa
in Curaçao is unlikely to result from sampling bias. This case supports the idea that current distribution patterns result from a combination of factors. Areas with high environmental suitability for
Galapa
might reflect the niche conservatism postulated for ninetines in general and present a typical environmental niche suitable for these spiders (cf.
), while limited dispersal abilities and geographic barriers result in highly suitable and geographically neighboring yet unoccupied areas.
